awd_titl_txt: ABI Development: A Genomic Data Mining Resource to Accelerate Genome-to-Phenome Discovery in Domesticated Animals
awd_abstract_narration:
Research on domesticated animals has significant impacts on society. For example, species such as pig, sheep, chicken and dog are used to model human biology, leading to discoveries with implications in human health and well-being. Understanding the genetic basis of disease leads to improved health and welfare of companion animals. Farm animal research leads to improvement of traits related to animal health and production, ultimately enhancing global food sustainability. To accelerate scientific discovery in animal genetics, an international consortium called "FAANG" (Functional Annotation of Animal Genomes) aims to generate comprehensive maps of functional elements in genomes of domesticated animals. Data generated by FAANG will enhance the use of animal models in the biological and biomedical sciences. It will hasten discoveries in fundamental biology, as well as those that impact human health, animal well-being and agricultural production. In order for the FAANG effort to have substantial impacts on science and society, the data must be accessible to scientists and students of diverse disciplines. Effective use of the FAANG data will require data mining tools that enable easy search and retrieval, along with a workforce trained in areas such as bioinformatics and cyberinfrastructure.

This project addresses the need for a high performance data mining resource that enables fine-grained querying and integrating the heterogeneous FAANG data with existing information, such as functions of known genes and research datasets. The specific aims of the project are to 1) develop FAANGMine - a high-performance data mining system that integrates genome assemblies and currently available annotation data for FAANG species, 2) extend FAANGMine by integrating new data generated by the FAANG Consortium, 3) create a FAANGMine user community that consists of students and scientists working on genetics of domesticated animal species. FAANGMine will empower animal researchers, with or without programming skills, to leverage the FAANG data in their research, thereby accelerating discoveries that elucidate the genetic basis of phenotypic variation. With the goal of fostering a FAANGMine user community, the proposed project will train over 30 graduate students and postdoctoral fellows through workshops and trainee visits with the FAANGMine developers. Moreover, undergraduate researchers will contribute to FAANGMine by developing demonstration projects. All trainees will have opportunities to work with data generated from cutting edge "omics" technologies, raising interest in STEM career pathways. The results of this project will be available at http://FAANGMine.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Due to a wealth of genetic and phenotypic diversity along with an abundance of genetic and phenotypic (trait) data, research on domesticated animals has significant impacts on science and society. Species such as pig, sheep, chicken and dog are used to model human biology. Understanding the genetic basis of disease leads to improved health and welfare of companion animals. Farm animal research leads to improvement of traits of economic importance, as well as traits related to animal health and well-being. Finally, investigation of domesticated animal genomes is used to address fundamental questions in evolution, selection, adaptation and domestication. To accelerate the prediction of how genomes impact phenotypic traits in domesticated animals, the international Functional Annotation of Animal Genomes (FAANG) Consortium has generated a wealth of genomic data that reveal functional elements that regulate genes. This data enables the comparison of the gene regulatory landscape across species to improve the application of animal models in the biological and biomedical sciences. The basic information delivered by the FAANG Consortium is also used to improve global food sustainability, a critical need for human society. To leverage the FAANG data, it is essential that scientists from diverse disciplines integrate it with their own research data and existing genome information.

To address the critical need for easy access and exploration of the FAANG data, we have developed the FAANGMine (http://faangmine.org) data mining and genome browser resource. FAANGMine provides simple and sophisticated search tools to enable researchers without programming skills to create and export customized datasets merged with their own research data for use in downstream analyses. The integration of FAANG data with existing genome and gene annotation data from a variety of sources allows users to query and visualize functional genome elements in the context of genes and associated biological information.

In this project we created a FAANGMine user community, and provided training in bioinformatics to numerous individuals, including members of underrepresented groups in STEM. Five undergraduate students, two graduate students and four scientific research analyst/programmers received training while developing, testing and creating examples for FAANGMine. In addition, we provided training in the use of the FAANGMine to 211 researchers, including 8 undergraduate students, 51 graduate students, 19 postdoctoral researchers and 133 faculty/research staff through remote tutorials (20 hours total). We hosted one visiting postdoctoral researcher for in-depth training in bioinformatics programming and the use of FAANGMine in research. We also demonstrated FAANGMine in five conference presentations.

 


Last Modified: 12/03/2024
Modified by: Christine G Elsik
